“Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com,” he mumbled with his mouth full of beef. “And it’s all thanks to Pashenka, your sweet little landlady. She loves doing stuff for me. I don’t ask, but hey, I’m not complaining. And here comes Nastasya with the tea. She’s quick! Nastasya, want some beer?”  
“Cut the nonsense!”  
“How about a cup of tea then?”  
“Maybe a cup of tea.”  
“Pour it out. Wait, I’ll do it myself. Sit down.”  

He poured two cups, left his dinner behind, and plopped back on the sofa. As before, he wrapped his left arm around the sick guy’s head, lifted him up, and fed him tea spoon by spoon, blowing on each spoonful like it was the secret to getting his friend better. Raskolnikov didn’t say a word or resist, even though he felt strong enough to sit up on his own and could’ve held a cup or even walked around. But for some strange reason, he decided to play it cool, hiding his strength and just listening to what was happening. Still, he felt a wave of disgust. After a dozen spoonfuls of tea, he suddenly let go, pushed the spoon away, and sank back into the pillow. He noticed there were actual nice pillows under his head now, down pillows in clean cases, and he made a mental note of it.  
“Pashenka better give us some raspberry jam today.”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov, while pretending to be weak, observes his surroundings and the care provided by his friend Razumihin.
